At the eye, ſhall have entrance at the next
Door, the ear; I'l make it known to him.
Good night.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You ſee how eaſily he's anſwerd now;
So will the reſt hereafter when they find
It is my pleaſure to be thus retir'd.

sp.speaker: Eth.
sp.l: Who are you? another knocks within.

sp.speaker: Phyſ.
sp.l: One that muſt have entrance; the Phyſitian;
One that brings the King a Preparative to ſleep.

sp.speaker: Eth.
sp.l: What is't compos'd of Prayers and meditations?

sp.speaker: Phyſ.
sp.l: My books yield no ſuch reading.

sp.speaker: Eth.
sp.l: Nor your Coat any ſuch practice.

sp.speaker: Phyſ.
sp.l: I come not to be mock'd, but as you tender
His Highneſſe reſt, let me approach him preſently.

sp.speaker: Eth.
sp.l: Good Sir, the King's at reſt already.

sp.speaker: Phyſ.
sp.l: Not aſleep?

sp.speaker: Eth.
sp.l: Faſt, faſt, and welcome Mr. Doctor.

sp.speaker: Phyſ.
sp.l: My Lord, you'l let him know my care I hope.

sp.speaker: Eth.
sp.l: I'l wake him with it when he has ſlept enough.

sp.speaker: Phyſ.
sp.l: Believe't my Lord, it was my care that charm'd him.

sp.speaker: Eth.
sp.l: He had not ſlept this fortnight elſe I warrant.

sp.speaker: Phyſ.
sp.l: Pray let him know ſo much.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ha, ha, they all deſire to have their care conſider'd,
Although in real act they merit nothing.

sp.speaker: Eth.
sp.l: How now? what ſawcie Knave is that? (Knock hard, Jeffrey within.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.l: You are coſen'd Couſin Lord, it is the Fool, Couſin;
How does my neam, the King?

sp.speaker: Eth.
sp.l: Go Fool, follow the Phyſitian, he can tell you.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.l: I aſk'd my Couſin Doctor already, and he ſaies,
My neam King's aſleep.

sp.speaker: Eth.
sp.l: And would not you be whipt to come to trouble him then?

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.l: No Couſin Lord, I come to ſing him a lullaby
Out of the dream of the Divel and Dives, ſhall
Make him ſleep till he wakes again, and 't be this month.

sp.speaker: Eth.
sp.l: Away you Fool, I'l ſet you a going.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.l: O Lord, O Couſin Lord, I cannot go for running.

sp.speaker: Eth.
sp.l: This will become a buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: But Ethelſwick, when I have declar'd my pleaſure,
As I'l appear, and publikely to morrow,
To give command that none upon their lives
Shall give you leſſe reſpect in this behalf
Then I my ſelf might claim, it will be eaſie.

sp.speaker: Eth.
sp.l: Again? Knock. Eaufrid within.

sp.speaker: Eaufr
sp.l: Where are you, my Lord Ethelſwick?

sp.speaker: Eth.
sp.l: Your pleaſure my Lord Eaufrid.

sp.speaker: Eauf.
sp.l: May I not ſee the King?

sp.speaker: Eth.
sp.l: If you dare take my word, the King commands
The contrary to all men but my ſelf
For this night; to morrow you may know
His highneſs further pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Eauf.
sp.l: May you enjoy
This night the greatneſſe of your Office;
To morrow if I have a King, I'l ſee and ſpeak with him.

sp.speaker: Eth.
sp.l: Not if he ſleep my Lord.

sp.speaker: Eauf.
sp.l: You ſay he ſleeps,
Go to, ſleep (quoth a!) yes, perhaps he ſleeps,
'Tis with his Anceſtors I fear.

sp.speaker: Eth.
sp.l: What ſhall I ſay my Lord?

sp.speaker: Eauf.
sp.l: I ſay, you do not well, my Lord, to keep
Our duties back from's Majeſty, that have
As well been truſted—I will keep the reſt:
But 'tis not well.

sp.speaker: Eth.
sp.l: I ſay, that you do worſe,
Officiouſly to interrupt his reſt.

sp.speaker: Eauf.
sp.l: I wiſh his reſt as well as you, my Lord,
Nay more: But I will keep the reſt till morning,
And ſo joy to the greatneſſe of your Office.

sp.speaker: Eth.
sp.l: How thinks your Majeſty of this? How will
Such as he is be ſatisfied in your abſence? Knock

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I'l ſchool 'em all.

sp.speaker: Eth.
sp.l: Yet more?

sp.speaker: Alf. Edel.
sp.l: My Lord, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Eth.
sp.l: What would you have?

sp.speaker: Alf.
sp.l: Open the door, and quickly.

sp.speaker: Eth.
sp.l: I may not.

sp.speaker: Edel.
sp.l: But you muſt; 'tis for the King.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How's that?

sp.speaker: Alf.
sp.l: Delay not, as you'l anſwer't;
The King's here.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Is the King there? what traytors voice is that?
Let 'em appear; (enter) ha! who made you King-makers?

sp.speaker: Edel.
sp.l: God ſave the King, and bleſſe us all from witchcraft.

sp.speaker: Alf.
sp.l: We durſt have ſworn we had had him faſt enough here.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Edel.
sp.l: Faſt aſleep Sir, aſleep Sir, look you here.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Let's ſee your may-game.

sp.speaker: Alf.
sp.l: Look you my Lord, and judge.

sp.speaker: Edel.
sp.l: Or if your Majeſty will know your ſelf,
(A leſſon which a King ſhould not diſdain
To learn) look here, and read the difference,
If you can find it.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Is he ſo like me to your apprehenſion?

sp.speaker: Eth.
sp.l: I am amaz'd to ſee't; your own eyes, Sir,
Cannot in likeneſſe anſwer each the other,
More then this Face doth yours; his hands, his legs,
All his dimenſions bear the ſame proportion
To outward ſeeming as your Royal Perſon.
Nature herſelf were ſhe now to behold
Her work on both of you, could ſcarce diſtinguiſh
By an exterior view, a difference.
Where did you find this ſleeper?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Peace, no more, ne're queſtion that; Cupid has heard my prayers.
Who ſaw you take him up?

sp.speaker: Edel.
sp.l: None but our ſervants,
Whom we diſmis'd in the ſame faith that we
Were of our ſelves, that 'twas your Majeſty;
And as we paſſd the Court none ſaw our carriage,
Which we brought thus obſcur'd that none might take
Notice of your infirmity.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: 'Twas well done;
Be ſecret ſtill; nay, I muſt charge you ſtrongly;
And if my power be not a ſpell ſufficient
To worke your ſecreſie, I'l take your heads
To mine own cuſtody.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Nay, I muſt truſt ye; harke you Ethelſwick.

sp.speaker: Eth.
sp.l: I underſtand your courſe.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Come, into our bed with him; gently, ſo:
Nay Sir, you ſhall have Noble Kingly uſage;
Never had ſtranger entertainment like him.
I'l give him all I have during his ſtay.
Exchange my ſelf with him, and be beholding
To him beſides for th' uſe I'l make of him.
I'l tell you all within: Love, that has ſent
This bleſſing in my way, when I was in
So great a ſtreight (I cannot think enough on't)
To bring new life unto my fainting hopes,
If now I ſerve thee not with ſtrength and ſkill,
Remove me as a Rebel to thy will.

div.head: SCEN. I.

sp.speaker: Offa.
sp.l: YOu are ſure they both are dead?

sp.speaker: 1. Outl
sp.l: Both dead and buried;
The Mould is not more dead from which
The gold was tane, which we attend for,
Then are their corps.

sp.speaker: 2. Outl.
sp.l: Nor is the Mine ſo deep,
As we laid them in grave; not out
Of charity, but for our own ſecurity.
That none might find or know them.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: That was well; but are they dead indeed?
You ſaw the old one dead before your ſword
Fail'd you, and you gave ground.
When a mans ſword is tane away, it fails him,
And when he runs away, he gives ground in our
Language.
Then we being two againſt one, we ſoon diſpatched him.
Alas he was e'en ſpent before, you ſaw
The worſt of him.

sp.speaker: Off
sp.l: But he's dead to y'are ſure?
Dead? ſblood, I have told you threeſcore times
They are both dead; ſo is our fellow too, poor Rogue:
He bid us take his ſhare betwixt us, and drink it
To the health of all the Furies in hell, to uſe
Him the more kindly. Will you diſcharge us Sir? we have
Waited for our hire, while we have loſt another bargain
Of blood worth two on't.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: They are both dead you ſay?
Give us our money Sir, and find 'em you alive, we'l kill
'Em again for nothing; and you or any friend of yours into
The bargain if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Stay; let me think.
What's the matter? your conſcience ſure is crop-ſick.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: My conſcience tells me 'twas a bloody buſineſſe, and that
To pay the price of their dear blood were to
Augment my ſin.
Is't come to this?—draw.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Nay here's your money Gentlemen, but you muſt ſtoop for't:
I dare not look upon the giving of it.
If that be all, the ſight of it ſhall never trouble you—oh. they ſink.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha. You have made my conſcience whole
Again with laughing. Why took ye not your money with ye to
Drink among the Furies? Ha, ha, ha. D'ye hear my friends?
Pray ſtay, take your money; are you ſo
Quickly out of hearing? What ſhallow Rogues were
Theſe till now? now they are deep enough, men of
Profound underſtanding; this Gimcrach I devis'd for
Their entertainment; where you ſhall faſt and welcome
Gentlemen, till you have tried the concluſion, whether Famine
Can break ſtone walls; I am ſure they are thick enough
To drown your cries, though they be lowder then the
Voice of vengeance. So ends their Scene. Some conſcience now
Would aſk me, why haſt thou
Diſpatch'd thy Father and thy Brother thus?
But mine informs me, I did very well.
Your reaſon Sir, replies the ſcrupulous conſcience?
Mine roundly anſwers that my brother was
Elder then I, and by right to inherit
My Fathers fair poſſeſſions, of which
I have ſo ſweetly taſted. But your Father
By a moſt dear and ſupernatural love
Gave you the greater bleſſing; & in time
Might have conferr'd all on you by your policy.
To this again I anſwer, that my Father,
Whoſe dotage meerly & not my deſerts
Made him ſo good to me, might in my abſence
Have idly grown as fond on tother ſide.
For to ſpeak truth, and not to wrong the dead,
My b • other was religious, pious, honeſt,
And was endued with all theſe unknown gifts
Which holy men call vertues; which in the end
If they be ſuffer'd to run on will find
Double reward, they ſay. His could not be
Found here, but in my loſſe, and by my Father.
Now if they may be had ith' tother world,
I am ſo far from being their hinderance,
That I have ſent them both the nigheſt way.
Many good reaſons more I could deliver,
But that I am prevented.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Ods my pity,
Be comforted good Madam, can you think
By caſting down your ſelfe to raiſe them up
From death again? what? you have yet a Brother
May ſtead you for a Father, Huſband,
Friend, or what you will.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: Gentle Nurſe, forbear me.

sp.speaker: Off
sp.l: Go prate among the ſervants.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: I have a mind to watch you though a little.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Y' have heard the news, and mourn for't I perceive,
Of the unfortunate ends of our dear Father,
And our beloved brother.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: E'en drowned in griefe too Brother.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Troth I was
Sunk over head and ears; but am crept out
Of ſorrows lake e'en dropping dry, as they ſay;
And have done what I can to ſhake it off.
And would now counſel thee, my beauteous Siſter,
To cleer thoſe looks again, that only can
Revive my drooping heart, we only are
Left now to be each others comforter.
I have made known my love to you.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: O my brother,
That knowledge is a grief of no leſſe horror,
Then was the bloody news that pierc'd my heart.
Mention that love no more, nor call it love,
Which is but foul deſire.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Peace, hear but this,
D'you think it is not love? would I deſire
You in that neereſt kind, if I not lov'd you?

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: What? love a Siſter ſo? are you a man?

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Sure I do hope ſo, and that you ſhall find it.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: Can you unto your ſhame ſeek my diſhonour?
To damn us both, in that abhorred way
Which by avoyding, man is beſt diſtinguiſh'd
From the moſt brutiſh beaſts.

sp.speaker: Off
sp.l: Peace again.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: I cannot, may not peace, nor ſuffer word
Importing ſuch a purpoſe pierce mine ears.
Twice have I beaten back your monſtrous luſt,
(Could I but call it luſt, it were too much
Though in a Monarch to my Virgin honour;
But in you beaſtly Inceſt) and before
I'l live in danger of one offer more,
I'l die by mine own hand.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: You ſhall not rob
Me ſo of my revenge, if you deny me.
And 'tis another argument of my love,
If't pleaſe you to collect it, that you have liv'd
Till now, ſtill obſtinate. But be you warn'd
And take withal to your conſideration
Your provident Father, and your valiant Brother,
(Whom you ſo priz'd above me) are not now
To overſee or ſide you.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: He indeed
Was a moſt vertuous Brother.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Therefore take
This for your lateſt warning;
This night to meet me in my full deſires,
In your as free embraces, or pale death.
Go clear your eyes, and think on't; but be ſure
You think to do withal as I command you.
I'l pitch thee headlong into Hell elſe. Come,
I know thou wilt affect me; can there be
A neerer or more requiſite love indeed
Then the ſweet mixture of a Brother and Siſter?
Well ſaid, there was a bluſhing ſmile, that gave me
Thy full conſent; O thou wilt raviſh me.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: Pray, let me think a little.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Prithe do.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: H'as taught me to diſſemble; Heaven that knows
My thoughts are chaſte and pure, will pardon me
I hope, if to preſerve my life and him
From greater ſin, I uſe a little of
The art too too much practic'd among women,
Of ſmooth hypocriſie. I know his heart is bloody;
And he may be too ſuddain, if I win not
Time on him, by ſome ſubtiler ſhift to wave
His foul attempts, untill I get free
Out of this gripe to uſe my liberty.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: What ſaies my Siſter now?

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: My Lord and brother.

sp.speaker: Off
sp.l: I marry, this begins well.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: That I love
Your noble perſon, nay am taken with it,
With more then ſiſterly affection, is
A truth no way to be diſſembled; you
Already like a well read ſcholler find it,
In Cupids love-letters my friend, my maiden bluſhes.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: This has ſome ſound in't.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: But when I conſider,
What ſcandal, or what too neer Affinity
In noble blood, and the Nobility of our houſe,
(Unfit to fall within the centre of the Law,
Or the conſtructions of mens ruder manners)
May caſt upon us.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Stay my lovely Mildred;
What? or whoſe eye, or thought, ſhall glance at us?
Whilſt we in ſafeſt privacy enjoy
The bliſſe of mutual pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: It is yet
Too intricate a doubt for me to find
A reſolution in. But my ſweet Lord,
(Oh that I could not call you Brother) then
I would be nearer to you then a Siſter.
So eager and ſo equal is my love
With yours; if you pleaſe but to give me time,
But one weeks liberty, to frame my ſelf
Obedient to your will in all, I now
Will give you a faithful pledge to render
The ſatisfaction you demand.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: A week; what pledge?

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: A loving kiſſe.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: You could not name a better,
Short of the further happineſſe I covet.
Give me't.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: But you ſhall ſwear by't that you will not
Abridge my liberty, nor urge your ſuit
Further theſe ſeven dayes.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: By this kiſſe I ſwear.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: My patience never bought a kiſs ſo dear.
But keep your vow.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Well, well, I'l do my beſt.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: He's not yet perfect, you muſt ſtrive my love,
To curb your hot deſires, as I do mine.
I could my ſelf dwell ever on your lips,
Never out go the circle of your arms.
Could I but hope to be your wife. But O,
What I have promis'd you, I muſt allow
At the time limited; till then urge it not.
For take my vow with yours, if you dare break it,
I dare to kill my ſelf; and by that time,
If I not yield my ſelf unto your will,
My life is yours either to ſave or kill.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Go, th'art a noble wench, enjoy thy liberty. Enter Edith.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: I have enough, liſtning is good ſometimes.
Good Heaven! who would have thought it? ſtay,
Let me not be too haſty.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Yet I fear,
I ſhall hardly hold out a week;
'Tis a great while believe't in ſuch a caſe
As this, for one to forbear his own Siſter,
That has ſo good a mind to't. And perhaps
This may be cunning in her to delude me.
Were not I better take her by ſurpriſe,
In a ſoft ſleep to night? ſure I ſhall keep her
From killing of her ſelf, till I be ſatisfied.
And then if ſhe be weary of her life,
I may be kind enough to help her out on't;
Becauſe ſhe ſayes ſhe loves me. Out you Beldame,
How in the name of Lucifer cam'ſt thou hither?

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: O my good Lord, I do beſeech your Honour,
Forbear your fury; I have ſuch a buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: To eaveſdrop have you not? I am not ſafe,
Unleſſe I kill this Witch.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: My Lord, my Lord,
You are the Lord that I do look to live by.
And if I die my Lord, you loſe the knowledge
Of ſuch a ſecret.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Pox upon your ſecret.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: 'Tis ſuch a privity.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Hell take your privity.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: You will repent in Hell my Lord, if you or I
Should leave the world before you know the thing
That I can open to you; which when I have unfolded,
Kill me if you pleaſe. I did but watch occaſion
To find you private to reveal it to you.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Will you be brief then?

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Thus it is my Lord,
My Lord, your Father's dead.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: And what of that?

sp.speaker: Ed
sp.l: So is your elder Brother.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: So they ſay forſooth.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: But are you ſure th'are dead?

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: I • ear this jade
Has overheard me.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: For d'ye ſee my Lord,
I would not in their life time have diſclos'd
This hidden matter for a whole worlds good.
And thus it is, your Father and your Brother
Being dead, Heaven reſt their ſouls.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Whats that to me?

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Nothing my Lord, but now comes that concerns you;
Your Father and your Brother being gone,
(Heaven reſt their ſouls) there I begin.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: You began there before, if that be the beginning,
Your for ever world without end
We ſhall never come at it.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Now that concerns you;
You think you have a Siſter.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Do I but think ſo?

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: No truly my good Lord, you do but think ſo.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Is Mildred dead? has ſhe deſtroy'd herſelf?
Now ſince ſhe left me here, to ſpight my love.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: You hear me not ſay ſo, I ſaw her not
Since I left both of you together here.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Unfold your riddle Sphinx, I'l dig it elſe
Out of your rotten belly. What's your meaning?

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Mildred is not your Siſter.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: How? not my Siſter?

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Not your own natural Siſter.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Becauſe ſhe is unnatural; didſt thou but know
What a poor eaſie requeſt ſhe deny'd me
Thou wouldſt ſay ſhe were unnatural indeed.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: I mean, ſhe was not born of the ſame mother,
Nor got by the ſame father that you were.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Speak that again; make but that good, I'l Saint thee.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: My Lord, I can and will maintain it, I,
Not only for ſome wrong ſhe did me lately,
Nor for the good my Lord that you may do me,
Though all the eſtates your own when ſhe's diſcarded;
But to let truth appear, which has been long
A burden, and an heavy burden, though I ſay't;
And ſo will any woman ſay, 'tis to keep councel
So many years together as I have done,
I had much a doe to keep it in, I wis,
In my good old Lords dayes. Lord how he lov'd her!
But few men know their children, that's the truth on't;
And let that go.

sp.speaker: Off
sp.l: I, quickly to the point.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: The point is this, I lov'd my old Lord well;
Therefore was loth to grieve him; and I lov'd
My good old Lady better; therefore I kept
Her councel to this hour: You now are all
That's left of'em; and whom ſhould I love now
But your ſweet ſelf my Lord? I'l tell you all:
This Mildred, whom you ſo long call'd Siſter,
Was not your Fathers, nor your Mothers child;
But in the abſence of your Father, when
Sixteen years ſince he was ſent by the King
Upon an embaſſie, your mother then with child,
By ſad miſchance brought forth a ſtill born babe;
At the ſame time a Lady nobly born
Whoſe huſband was in Exile, brought forth this,
This Lady Mildred.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Then ſhe is nobly born?

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Yes, and by womans ſlight, of which this is
Not firſt example, th' Infants were exchang'd;
Becauſe your loving father might find joy
In a fair daughter at his home-return.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Canſt thou prove this?

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: If in three dayes I do not
Make it appear moſt plain to you, multiply
Your wrath upon me.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Do ſo; and doſt hear?
I'l never call old woman witch hereafter
What e're I think. We may be married now,
And Mildreds love may freely anſwer mine.
We now may ſafely mix, and to't again,
Strange ſtrong events are labouring in my brain.
Come you with me.

sp.speaker: Eth.
sp.l: What fury has poſſeſs'd 'em? all our art,
And the Kings policy will be prevented,
By the brain-giddineſs of theſe wilful Lords.

sp.speaker: Edel.
sp.l: We have no way my Lord, but to give way
Unto their violent rage, & quit the Court.

sp.speaker: Eth.
sp.l: And ſince we can make good our place no longer,
Poſt after our King Maſter, & leave them.
With their new King at home here, that's as mad
As they.

sp.speaker: Edel.
sp.l: And madder too; I cannot wonder
More what he is, then at the fate that ſent him.

div.stage: Enter Theodwald, Eaufride, Guard, Phyſitian, 2. Attendants.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: My Lord, both in the King and States behalf,
In which you may excuſe us.

sp.speaker: Eauf.
sp.l: Sh't, ſh't, let him take it
How he or will or dare, we have agreed.
The body of the Council have decreed it
You muſt depart the Court.

sp.speaker: Eth.
sp.l: Muſt?

sp.speaker: Eauf.
sp.l: Muſt and ſhall,
You and your trim conſederate; you have had
The rule here over your Ruler, till you have made him
Wild, frantick, mad, and us too; God forgive me
For ſaying ſo, almoſt as mad as he;
I hope it is no treaſon.

sp.speaker: Edel.
sp.l: No, cauſe you ſaid almoſt;
But had you ſaid you had been full as mad,
You had paſs'd a Subjects boldneſſe.

sp.speaker: Eauf.
sp.l: Take 'em hence;
Thruſt 'em out oth' Court.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: Nay, without violence.

sp.speaker: Eth.
sp.l: Well my Lord, when we ſee the King in's wits,
We'l tell him of our uſage, that he may thank you.

sp.speaker: Eauf.
sp.l: In the mean time go travel on adventures,
Whilſt we do our indeavour to amend
What you have marr'd by ſcrewing the Kings brain
Into the nick of Order once again. (Put forth a bed, Anthynus on it bound)
See, ſee, my Lord, how they have kept him dark,
Manacl'd and bound on's bed? was ever King
Us'd thus? for pities ſake unbind him quickly.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: What Fiends or Fairies are ye?

sp.speaker: Phyſ.
sp.l: Let his paſſion
A little vent it ſelf, e're you unbind him.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: What? new tormentors? or into what way
Of further miſchief do ye mean to throw me?

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: We come to bring your Highneſſe comfort.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Highneſſe?
Have you that mockery for me too? I told
The reſt that ſlav'd me with that attribute,
From whence I came, who, what I was, and all
The ſtory of my fathers wrongs, and mine
(Too many ever to have been, but heaven
Mark'd 'em out for us) and I told 'em too
What I had undertane by Watching, Faſting,
Prayers too (unfit to boaſt of) with the Induſtry
I practic'd to have found my wounded Father.
For which (as though I durſt have faith in merits)
They mock'd me with the title of a King,
And bound me here as they thought to believe it.
'Tis a new way of puniſhment; and were due
To one that thought his duty meritorious.
But I will break theſe Gives, and with my teeth
Tear off theſe manacles.

sp.speaker: Phyſ.
sp.l: O do not ſtrive my Liege.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Thy Liege, Dog-leech? are you at that garb too?
I wiſh I had one finger looſe to fillip out
Thy brains and ſkill together for the Ratcatchers.

sp.speaker: Phyſ.
sp.l: He thinks my ſkull's made but of urinal mettal.

sp.speaker: Theod
sp.l: Be patient Sir.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Sir, yet may be endured.

sp.speaker: Eauf
sp.l: Have but a little patience, we'l unlooſe you.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: A grave perſwaſion to a man that's tied to't.
Humb, humb, humb.

sp.speaker: Eauf.
sp.l: Beſhrew their heards that us'd him thus to vex him.
How do you like him Doctor?

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: Did you mark
His talk of wrongs, and of a wounded Father?
And how he will not hear of being a King?

sp.speaker: Phyſ.
sp.l: I, all, all, I know all; ſuch fancies fall
Naturally into this diſeaſe, which now
Is almoſt a wild Phrenſie, that will ſeldome
Suffer the Patient think himſelf to be
The perſon that he is; nor oftentimes the Creature,
But ſome four-footed Beaſt, or feather'd Fowl:
But could I faſten but a ſlumber on him,
Which muſt be the firſt entrance to my work.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Have you concluded yet your barbarous councel?
If not, take my advice with ye: call the King,
The King with whoſe authority you ſcorn me;
Let him but hear (for you will never tell him)
From my own lips how willingly I'l give
My voice unto his marriage; and I'm ſure
He'l ſet me free; at leaſt by death.

sp.speaker: Eauf.
sp.l: Alas,
What King? what freedome would you have?
You are our King, and ſhall command your freedom,
And all our lives, would you but ſleep a while.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Sleep? make no doubt of that; look, I can ſleep,
With as much eaſe as one bound in a Cart,
Driving to execution. But do you hear?
My vow was not to ſleep nor eat untill
I had perform'd a work, which I ſhall never,
Never accompliſh, now my vow is broken.
For they by witchcraft charm'd me into ſleep,
And tempted me with meat at unawares,
Before my ſleep-drown'd ſenſes were collected;
And put me on theſe unknown garments here,
With an hayl Maſter; ſo betray'd me into
This irkſome folly, or this fooliſh thraldome.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: 'Twas a raſh vow, and ſo well broke; you now
Shall be releas'd: unbind him at my peril.
Theſe rigorous courſes have done hurt upon him;
We have provided otherwiſe to pleaſe you;
For we have call'd Theodrick home again
Your Favourite, whoſe abſence was a grief to you;
Nay more, becauſe 'tis thought your languiſhing love
Bred your diſtemper, we have taken care
For haſtning of your marriage; your fair Queen
Is ſent for, and at hand to eaſe your ſorrow.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: My Favourite, and my Queen! leave theſe abuſes;
My hands and feet are now at liberty (Strikes and kicks.)

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: So is our duty, and if your Majeſty
Will tread our due allegiance into duſt,
We are prepar'd to ſuffer.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Would to heaven,
I could unfold this myſtery.

sp.speaker: Eauf.
sp.l: See my Lord,
Theodrick is come.

sp.speaker: Theodr.
sp.l: Moſt gracious Sir,
That I have ſuffred under your diſpleaſure,
In being barr'd your preſence, which no leſſe
Then the all cheering Sun gave life to me,
Was not ſo much my grief, as not to know
What my tranſgreſſion was; and let me now
Implore your mercy ſo far as to name it;
Which if I cannot cleer me of, I'l loſe my life, and willingly.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: If I could think this ſerious, 'twere enough
Almoſt to turn my ſorrows into laughter.

sp.speaker: Theodr.
sp.l: O turn not from me royal Sir, t' augment
Your Highneſſe diſpleaſure; but in caſe you will not
Be pleas'd to name my treſpaſſe, give me leave
To ſpeak what I ſuppoſe has troubled you,
And caus'd me cauſeleſly to be ſuſpended.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: I feel a ſecret inſtigation in me,
I hope by ſome good Angel that inclines me,
At laſt to yield a little to theſe men.
What wouldſt thou ſay?

sp.speaker: Theodr.
sp.l: My Lords, and all forbear
The preſence; never fear, all ſhall be well.

sp.speaker: Theodw.
sp.l: Heaven grant it.

sp.speaker: Eauf.
sp.l: Was not this my policy,
To ſend for him? more, was it not my wit
To faſhion letters as with's own hand
To fetch the Queen? you'l ſee more at her coming.

sp.speaker: Theodr.
sp.l: May't pleaſe you now but to review theſe Pictures.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Good memory help me; this is of the Queen,
The cruel Queen that baniſh'd my good Father;
And this the lively Image of my Siſter.

sp.speaker: Theodr.
sp.l: Now may it pleaſe your grace to recollect,
How when I told you this was my fair Miſtreſſe,
Your paſſion firſt ſiez'd on you; and pardon Royal Sir,
If I have ſince conjectured my tranſgreſſion
Was meerly this, that I lov'd one ſo fair,
I dare not yet ſay fairer then your choice.
But freely thus, to expiate my treſpaſſe,
As I reſign the Picture, I give up
All intereſt in her perſon, never more
Beyond your free conſent to ſee that Beauty.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: I have found all the error, and am taught
By hidden inſpiration to make uſe on't. (Genius ſhall whiſpers him.)
Give me freſh rayment, I'l take all upon me
(Their Crown if they will give it) yet me thinks
This is ſo like a dream—where elſe can be
King Oſriick all this while, that he comes not
To throw me out of this uſurped right?
Strange and new thoughts poſſeſſe me. (Gen. whiſpers) Now I call
To mind the viſion that I had of being
Call'd to the Throne of the weſt Saxons Kings.
It muſt be by this Queen, whom how to love
I cannot find. My Genius promps me, yes
I hear it now, as by an Angel ſpoke.
And that my vow was raſhly made, well broke;
I am confirm'd, & come ſhe I am for her. (puts on Hat, Feather, and Cloke) ex. Genius.
Well ſaid Theodrick; (Theodrick is his name?)
How do I look Theodrick?

sp.speaker: Theodr.
sp.l: I can find
But little change, which I allow to ſickneſſe.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Well ſaid, thou never flattereſt.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.l: News, neam King, news, news;
News that will make thee well, beeſt thou never ſo ſick.
News that beeſt thou never ſo well, will make thee ſick.
News that will make thee mad, beeſt thou never ſo tame.
News that beeſt thou never ſo mad, will make thee tame.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: What's thy news?

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.l: A wife, a wife, a wife can do all this.
The Queen is come, and all my Couſin Lords
Are gone to fetch her in in pompe: Oh ho,
Knight me, oh Knight me quickly for my news.

sp.speaker: Theodr.
sp.l: Away you fool.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.l: Away you Favourite.
Hinder me not unleſſe I propheſie,
Kings, Fools and Favourites never ſhall agree.
And many years after we are in our graves,
Fools ſhall be Knights, and Favourites ſhall be—known
From black Sheep, I propheſie.
Oh ho, ſhe comes, ſhe comes; now neam King,
Bear up ſtiff before and meet her. Here's a day,
And a night towards indeed. Oh ho, the houſe,
Begins to reel already, and all our brains turn
Round; oh ho.

div.stage: Enter Ʋſhers bare, Kelriick and Elkwin, Theodwald and Eaufride, a Cardinal, the Queen, two Ladies bearing up her Train, Followers, the Queen Bertha kneels, Anthynus as King takes her up; kiſſes her; they confer; the four Lords ſalute and confer; Theodwald and Eaufride give their ſuppoſed Kings hand to the Cardinal. Kelriick and Elkwin give their Queens hand to the Cardinal; the Cardinal joyns their hands, Anthynus and Bertha kiſſe; all the Lords embrace; the Exeunt in ſtate as before.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.l: Oh what a night will here be?
what a night will here be?
What a beaſt am I? that I have not at leaſt half
A ſcore of my wholeſome Countrey Laſſes with child now,
That forty weeks hence the Queen might have her
Choice of Nurſes; there had been a thriving way to raiſe
My fortunes indeed. Oh what a night will here be!

div.head: SCEN. I.

sp.speaker: Mild
sp.l: HElp, help, oh help.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Your cries will be in vain.
'Tis not in the power of any fleſh but yours,
To allay, or to prevent my heat of blood.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: O you diviner powers that ordain'd chaſtity
To be a vertue, lend your ſtrength to guard it.

sp.speaker: Off
sp.l: Thy cries ſhall be as fruitleſs as thy life
If thou offend'ſt me with 'em; hear but this
Impertinently peeviſh maid, and tremble
But to conceive a diſobedient thought
Againſt my will. Canſt thou without my favour,
Be better then a begger?

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: Yet a begger
Is better then a Whore.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: How canſt thou judge
That knowſt not what is either? let a wench
That knows what's what, or has been both, maintain it;
But this is from the purpoſe; I am ſo far
From caſting of thee off to be a begger,
As I intend to make thee my rich equal,
And not a Whore, but wife; you know your Nurſe
Has undertaken to find it lawful for us
To marry; and canſt thou with modeſty
Deny me preſent pleaſure, that within theſe three dayes
Shall confer honour on thee for thy life?

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: Would you firſt ſpoil my honor to repair it?

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: 'Tis mine when I contract for't.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: Not before
Our Covenant is paſs'd; that is, the Prieſt
Has joyn'd our hearts and hands.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: By this account,
A man backs not his Horſe before he's paid for't;
Nor puts his noſe into a houſe before
He buyes the Leaſe on't; leave your preciſe folly,
Madam formality; force me not to force thee,
Yield with that very breath thou now draweſt in,
Or it returns thy laſt.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: My Lord, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: This Witch or Divel haunts me.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: O my Lord,
I told you late a wonder; I bring now
A miracle, a miracle.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: What with a miſchief?

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Your Brother is ſurviv'd from death again;
My Lord Anthynus is come home and ſafe,
The Heavens be prais'd.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: O grant that it be true.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Out Hag.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Nay, run me in as far as you can if I lie;
Up to the Hilts if I lie.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: What canſt thou mean by this?

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Nay, what he means I knew not, for he denies his name,
Sayes he is not Anthynus, but a Northumbrian Gentleman;
And deſires conference with my Lady Mildred
From the fine Lord was here (what call you him?)
The Kings great Favourite; But if I am I,
If you are you, if any thing be any thing,
It is Anthynus.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Go you to your Chamber,
And be not ſeen I charge you. Let him enter,
But firſt ſend in my ſervants.
I did miſtruſt he liv'd; O thoſe falſe Villains,
That fac'd me down they kill'd him, may they be
A year a famiſhing. Have you tricks Anthynus?
How can he thinke, though he diſguis'd his name
Or Countrey, that we ſhould not know his perſon?
What ſhould his aim or drift be? ſtay, perhaps
He does ſuſpect I was in the action
Againſt my fathers life and his, & thinks him dead,
So ſteals upon me thus as his own ghoſt,
To terrifie my conſcience, ſhallow, ſhallow;
But I'l ſo fit him; It is moſt evidently he.

div.stage: Enter Oſriick, Alfride, four Servants, at the other d • or Arnold.

sp.speaker: Oſr.
sp.l: My Lord, how e're
Some of your ſervants are pleas'd to make themſelves
Merry with a pretended knowledge of me,
I do preſume your honour cannot know me.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: From one ſo falſe never came clearer truth.

sp.speaker: Oſr.
sp.l: What means your honour?

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: It is true, my honour
Cannot, nay, dares not know thee for a Brother,
Although mine eyes through tears of grief and anger,
Diſcern the monſter I have often call'd ſo.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: This is moſt ſtrange.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Look that he come not near me;
Perfidious Parricide, haſt thou kill'd my Father?
Deſtroy'd the life that gave thee life? and now
Seek'ſt by ſurprize to take mine too?

sp.speaker: Oſr.
sp.l: Pray hear me.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Upon him all at once, hew him in pieces;
I'l bear you out in't; he has kill'd your Lord.

sp.speaker: Oſr.
sp.l: Forbear your outrage.

sp.speaker: Alfr.
sp.l: Give us leave to ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Off
sp.l: Villains, are they to be obey'd or I?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: My Lord, your judgement is too raſh upon them.
Fellows forbear, and forbear you my Lord,
You ſhall not ſo heap blood upon your head;
I lov'd my Lord your father, and do prize
His blood and memory, as becomes a Servant
Of the beſt rank: And if at moſt and worſt
My Lord Anthynus here ſtand guilty of
His fathers death, you muſt not be his Judge,
Nor we his Executioners.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Are you
Become my maſter, you old Ruffian?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: No,
Your Servant Sir, but ſubject to the Law;
The Law that muſt determine this mans cauſe,
Not you, nor we, what ever he deſerves.
And till he ſhall be cenſur'd by that law
We'l find a Priſon for him.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: I, to Priſon with him.

sp.speaker: Oſr.
sp.l: Will you but hear yet how you are miſtaken?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Pray heaven we be, as you may clear your ſelf;
That's all the harm we wiſh you; this muſt be
Your courſe my Lord; would you heap blood upon you?

sp.speaker: Alfr.
sp.l: Let me but ſpeak a word.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: As we go twenty.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Away with 'em. Exeunt.
I could have lik'd the other ſhorter way
Much better; but my knaves will have it thus,
Yet not to wrong 'em, ſimple honeſty
May be in ſuch ſometimes as well as me.

div.stage: Enter Carpenter, Maſon, Smith, in Divels halits; two dark Lanthorus, a Pickaxe and a Rope, with an Engine faſtned to a Poſt, and a bunch of Picklocks.

sp.speaker: Maſ.
sp.l: Prethee tread ſoftly yet a little further,
And we are ſafe.

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.l: Hark, heard ye nothing? whiſt.

sp.speaker: Carp.
sp.l: I never knew Thieves ſo timerous as you are.
Can we expect a booty without boldneſſe?
Beſides, have we not ſhapes if we were ſpyed,
Able to fright better Believers then
My politick Lord oth' houſe here.

sp.speaker: Maſ.
sp.l: Hark prethee.

sp.speaker: Carp.
sp.l: All's ſure I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.l: I pray it prove ſo.

sp.speaker: Carp.
sp.l: Pray on I prethee; prayers become this coat,
Like ſwearing in a Surpliſſe; tuſh, they are all,
All the whole houſe aſleep, and I heard nothing
As we paſs'd through it, but uſuall ſleepy ſounds,
Puffing and blowing, ſhorting farting and ſuch like.
Yes, I cry mercy, as we paſs'd by the Butlers chamber,
I heard his bed crackle ſhrewdly, and I doubt,
The Dary-maid and he were jumbling of
A Poſſet together. Come, now we are ſafely arriv'd at the
Fountain of our hopes, the well of comfort. Smith, lay
Down your Picklocks, they have done well their office in our paſſage hither. Maſon,
Advance your Pickaxe, whilſt the Carpenter ſquares out
Our new work; now for the honour of Artificers; here, here,
Here is the Trap-door, the mouth of the rich mine, which
We'l make bold to open. And let men of our Occupations
Learn the way that many grow rich by, and
No body knows how they come by their wealth. That
Is, when they make ſuch concavities as theſe, for
Rich men to hide their treaſure in, that they
Make alſo a privy way for themſelves to come and
Take a ſhare on't.

sp.speaker: Maſ.
sp.l: This covetous Lord by this time has laid in
An unknown deal of wealth, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.l: But we'l not take away too much at once.

sp.speaker: Carp.
sp.l: No, we'l but piddle; we'l not take above
A thouſand pounds to night. (opens) So, I'l go down;
And when I ſhake the rope, then crane me up again; give me one of
The Lanthorns: So, ſo, ſo, let me down handſomely;
I'l warrant you money, the Divel and all before day yet.

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.l: Nay, if we get off clear but with a thouſand pound
Amongſt us, it will ſerve for drinking
Money till we come for more.

sp.speaker: Maſ.
sp.l: This money will come luckily for a better purpoſe.
I have three baſtards at nurſe and a fourth in the Paniers.
The rope ſtirs; pull luſtily, this pull for a
Thouſand pound. (Outlaw comes up)

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.l: I fear 'tis light gold, methinks he does not weigh
So heavy as he went down. Comrade, what haſt thou
Brought? what ail'ſt thou? canſt not ſpeak? I hope thou
Wert not frighted.

sp.speaker: 1. Outl.
sp.l: O help! where am I? drawn from one hell into another? ha!

sp.speaker: Maſ.
sp.l: Come, leave your fooling, what money have you?

sp.speaker: 1. Outl.
sp.l: Had I the price of Kingdoms I'd give all
But for one bit of meat; but I have none.

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.l: Slid, he would coſen us; how do you look when you lie?
Oh me!

sp.speaker: Maſ.
sp.l: What aileſt thou?

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.l: This is not he; it is a gaſtly ſpirit.

sp.speaker: 1. Outl.
sp.l: What? are you men?

sp.speaker: Maſ.
sp.l: Yes, but we have play'd the Divels, till we have
Got a ſpirit betwixt us.

sp.speaker: 1. Outl.
sp.l: If you be men, help me to food, a little food.

sp.speaker: Maſ.
sp.l: What art thou that canſt look thus Piepeckt, Crowtrod, or Sparrow-blaſted? ha!

sp.speaker: 1. Outl.
sp.l: O, I am pin'd with hunger.

sp.speaker: Maſ.
sp.l: Here, ſtay thy ſtomach; there's a cruſt I brought
To ſtop the open mouth of the Maſtive, if he had flown at us.

sp.speaker: Carp.
sp.l: O pull, pull away.

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.l: There he is now I am ſure.

sp.speaker: Carp.
sp.l: I ſhall be devour'd elſe.

sp.speaker: Maſ.
sp.l: Whats the matter Fellow?

sp.speaker: Carp.
sp.l: Take his teeth out o' me, I cannot tell you elſe.
sp.stage: (Pull up Carp. an Outl. hanging on him)

sp.speaker: Maſ.
sp.l: O Cannibal! wilt thou eat a Carpenter?

sp.speaker: 2. Outl.
sp.l: O meat, meat, if you be men.

sp.speaker: Maſ.
sp.l: No, we are Divels; but hare's another cruſt for thee
What e're thou art; we have play'd the Thieves to
Very good purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Carp.
sp.l: He has gnaw'd a piece of my Flank out with's teeth;
And miſs'd very narrowly certain members of more moment,
They'd have gone down glib with him; now in the
Divels name, what are ye?

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.l: Until their cruſts be done they cannot tell us.

sp.speaker: Maſ.
sp.l: Come, I do ſuſpect the ſubtilty of this cruel politick
Lord; would we were well out on's houſe. No noiſe my
Maſters, and we'l bring you to meat enough; and then
We'l hear your ſtory, and tell our own; a word more
Here, may coſt all our lives.

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.l: Take up your tools and lead the way.

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.l: Come, ſoftly, ſoftly then.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: I will away this night.

sp.speaker: Maſ.
sp.l: Peace, hark.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: But Madam.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Had you the only Tongue of all perſwaſion,
So much I prize my life, & honour more,
I would not miſſe this opportunity
For all that you could ſay.

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.l: Are not theſe Sprites?

sp.speaker: Carp.
sp.l: No evil ones I'l warrant, they are ſo white;
Hark a little more.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: To night he's troubled 'bout Anthynus coming,
So that he will not think of luſt or wantonneſſe.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: That trouble keeps him waking; and I fear
Will rather ſpur him forwards then withhold him.

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.l: They talk methinks; but I cannot hear what
For ſhaking.

sp.speaker: Carp.
sp.l: Take heed thou doſt not jingle thy Picklocks,; ſlid,
They'l ring up the houſe like a larum bell.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Well, ſince you are ſo reſolute, would we were out of the
Houſe once, if we be taken, 'tis not the price of
A million of Maiden-heads, as the market goes, can ſave
Our lives.

sp.speaker: Carp.
sp.l: Good, I have found what ſprites they be. They
Muſt needs be the wenches that I ſuſpected were in
The Butlers chamber, and made the ſtiff ſtanding bedſtead that
I ſet up but laſt week, crack like a wicker chair.
Ah Rogues! I heard ye.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Oh me! we are undone and taken.

sp.speaker: Maſ.
sp.l: I'm glad 'tis no worſe.

sp.speaker: Carp.
sp.l: Peace, if you have a mind to ſcape out oth' houſe alive.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: Come Nurſe, my fear is over, if they be
Men, and bring us out oth' houſe,
They cannot be ſo dangerous as he I ſcap'd.

sp.speaker: Carp.
sp.l: Did he ſo put thee to't, my little Buſtlepate? what a ſtout blade's this Butler?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Theſe are good Fellows Nurſe.

sp.speaker: Carp.
sp.l: Yes faith, and fear you nothing for all our diveliſh
Outſides; if we ſcape out o' the houſe, you ſ • ape, and
If we fail, our necks are ſure to hang by't; and ſo
On there afore once more in the name of darkneſſe.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: If my attempt now fail, may my repulſe
Strike luſt for ever out of countenance.
It is decreed ſhe ſleeps with me or death

sp.speaker: 1. Outl.
sp.l: S'death, it is he.

sp.speaker: 2. Outl.
sp.l: Let us fall to and beat him.

sp.speaker: Carp.
sp.l: As you can hope for meat again, or life,
Look big, and uſe no words; and ſo glide by.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: The night, the place, her fate, and my deſire,
Do all conſpire unto my wiſh'd advantage.
And ſo I come coy Damoſel.
sp.stage: (Hide the women under their habits, and ſo Exeunt all but Offa.)
sp.l: Ha? how? why? where? who? or what can you or I be?
They are all gone, and I am tottering left
Upon an Earthquake; gentle, holla, holla,
Set not too hard old Ops, thou'lt ſhake thy rider,
Through thy chinky wrinkles into Limbo.
I ſhall ſinke piecemeal if thou trot ſo hard.
So, ſo, ſo, Holla, holla, gentle earth.
Open not here, not near that part of thee
That has but now diſgorg'd thoſe famiſh'd ghoſts,
That with the Furies would have beckned me
Along to hell with'em; ſo, let me down,
I muſt not follow yet, but ſleep and think upon't.
I will come time enough you need not fear.
But firſt creep back to bed, as nothing were.

sp.speaker: Oſr.
sp.l: You have told me wonders, which have pierc'd my ſoul
With horror and amazement; yet I muſt confeſſe,
In all that I am like to ſuffer, heaven is juſt,
Whilſt wrath my wilfulneſſe has pull'd upon me;
Yet pardon, ſince thou gav'ſt me that affection
That wandred with me in this oblique courſe,
This unquoth way, with which I have not ſtray'd
Further then love might lead an humane frailty.

sp.speaker: Eth.
sp.l: You do conſider well, my Lord, and we
Beſeech you ſtrive to counter-check theſe croſſes
Still with your Kingly reaſon.

sp.speaker: Oſr.
sp.l: Yes, and fall upon our preſent buſineſſe; there you find me
Out of a ſpacious Kingdom of mine own,
Shut in a narrow Priſon; whilſt the brother
Of her, whoſe love I came to ſeck, has married
The Queen I might have had; before I have ſeen
His Siſter; there was a quick expedition.

sp.speaker: Eth.
sp.l: My Lord, for that before you leſt the Court
In your ſuppos'd diſtraction; the ore-buſie Lords
Eaufride and Theodwald, out of ſtrong conceit
The ſight of her would cure you, feign'd your letters
Which fetch'd the Queen; then baniſh'd us the Courth,
Before we could take notice; we had been
Strong Traitors elſe to let that match go forwards.
Nor heard we of it until now the Poſt
That brings the news oth' Kings and Queens approach
Arriv'd here in the City.

sp.speaker: Oſr.
sp.l: All think him then their King ſtill?

sp.speaker: Eth.
sp.l: Yes, yes, and though he told us who he was;
The overwiſe Lords imputed that to his madneſſe.

sp.speaker: Oſr.
sp.l: It ſeems he was not ſo mad, but he could take
The Queen into my bed.

sp.speaker: Eth.
sp.l: Where ſhe lik'd him ſo well
That ſhe now brings him home unto her own.
Still thinking him your perſon.

sp.speaker: Oſr.
sp.l: Whilſt I lie here for his,
Accus'd of Parricide; but I will not
Reveal my ſelf till trial. (Ent. Mildred)
Now all my ſufferings are turn'd into delightful recreations.
Faireſt of Virgins welcome; marvail not
That at firſt ſight I knew you, when my heart
Wears the Impreſſion of your Portraiture;
And all my intellectual faculties
Bow to no other object but your beauty.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: O Sir, lay by this high diſſimulation;
For though I find you now are not my brother.

sp.speaker: Oſr.
sp.l: Lo ye, ſhe knows I am not Anthynus.
Her vertue like the Sun will clear the miſt
Of error we were loſt in.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: Not Anthynus?
Yes, the bright Sun diſcovers not a truth
More evident then that you are Anthynus
Nor ever ſhin'd on man I lov'd ſo well,
Or hop'd to marry, ſince you are not my brother.

sp.speaker: Oſr.
sp.l: I underſtand not this.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: Indeed I came
To tell you ſo, and could you clear your hand
Of the foul ſtain of blood you are accus'd of,
Were I ſole monarcheſs of all this Iſland,
I'd kneel to beg a brides place in your bed.

sp.speaker: Oſr.
sp.l: If I can clear my ſelf?

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: Nay, mark me further;
If you clear not your ſelf, I'l not outlive you,
To call to mind the man that I ſo lov'd,
Butcher'd his Father; though he were not mine,
I lov'd him as a father; oh good heaven!
How good? how reverend a man was he?

sp.speaker: Oſr.
sp.l: Weep not, but hear me; or hear me though you weep;
I am not Anthynus.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: I may ſay as well,
I do not love you.

sp.speaker: Oſr.
sp.l: I never had an hand
In blood of any man.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: Prove that, I am yours.

sp.speaker: Oſr.
sp.l: Fetch me a Prieſt.

sp.speaker: Edel.
sp.l: I ſaw one i'th next room
Drinking and ſinging catches with ſome Priſoners.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Withhold your hands, Anthynus now again,
Fair Lady, is your brother.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: Why did you mock me then?

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: To ſave you from your brother Offa's luſt,
I feign'd that you were not his Siſter;
In hope to marry you, he might forbear
His diveliſh purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: Now I am loſt for ever,
In being the Daughter of a murder'd Father,
And made uncapable of you in marriage.

sp.speaker: Oſr.
sp.l: Yet hear me, and be comforted.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: O me!

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Hark my Lord Anthynus.

sp.speaker: Oſr.
sp.l: I do not know that name.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Go to, go to; nor you do not remember
How I behav'd my ſelf upon the eating of Spurging
Comfects, that your Brother Offa gave me,
And laid the fault on you; pray Jove, I ſay, this murder
Be no more his fault then yours.

sp.speaker: Oſr.
sp.l: Hark, the wide world abroad is fill'd with joy,
And muſt we only be ſhut from it? now.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: My Lord Anthynus.

sp.speaker: Oſr.
sp.l: Still muſt I be Anthynus?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: You are call'd unto your Trial.

sp.speaker: Oſr.
sp.l: Who are my Judges?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: Thoſe that are bribe-free I dare warrant 'em.
It may perhaps go ſomewhat the harder with you;
For nothing but white innocence can quit you,
Pray heaven you hav't about you; even the King
And Queen, the Queen and King I ſhould have ſaid,
For ſhe's our Soveraign, 'tis her Law muſt do it.

sp.speaker: Oſr.
sp.l: What King do you mean then?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: King Oſriick; you know nothing.

sp.speaker: Oſr.
sp.l: Yes, I know him as well as he knows himſelf.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: Take heed Sir what you ſay.

sp.speaker: Oſr.
sp.l: I fear him not,
But am as good as he; now carry me for ſomething.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: O pray take heed.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: Peace, he did not ſay ſo.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: Slid, he's as mad as his brother Offa.

sp.speaker: Oſr.
sp.l: Is Offa mad?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: O quite beſides himſelf, and talks the ſtranglieſt
Of his fathers murder, your running away
And the deſire he has to hang his brother here;
And then he is haunted with ſprites too, they ſay;
You will know all anon; will you go my Lord?

sp.speaker: Oſr.
sp.l: Yes, will you be ſo kind as to ſee my Trial?

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: Indeed I muſt not leave you.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: 'Tis a kinde part indeed, and may become
A Siſter; like the wiſe that would not leave
Her huſband till ſhe ſaw him totter.
Set the beſt foot forward, and the beſt face
You can, my Lord, upon the buſineſſe.

div.stage: Enter Theodwald and Eaufride, Kelrick and Elkwin, Theodrick, Anthynus and Bertha.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Long live King Oſriick and Queen Bertha.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: I joyn with ye in your wiſhes for the Queen;
And wiſh well to King Oſriick as a ſtranger.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: But will no longer perſonate him;
For now be it known to you that I am no Oſriick;
But he that warns you call me ſo no more.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: What means my love?

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Nay, Madam, 'tis moſt ſerious.

sp.speaker: Kelr. Elkw.
sp.l: Bleſſe us!

sp.speaker: Theodw.
sp.l: He's madder now then e're he was.

sp.speaker: Eauf.
sp.l: I am at my wits end too; if marriage
Will not tame him, I know not what to ſay to't.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: I have told you truth, and your fair grace can witneſſe
How violently I was thrown upon the fortune,
I thank thoſe provident Lords, againſt my vow.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: I take it as the providence of Heaven;
And from the Son of that moſt injur'd Father,
Whom now in my joys ſtrength I could ſhed tears for.
I yield you are my head, and I your handmaid.
sp.stage: (She ſets him down, and kneels; he takes her up.)

sp.speaker: Eauf.
sp.l: So, ſo, a few nights trial has got her liking
For ever faſt enough; what notable old Cockſcombs
Have we been made? nay, made ourſelves indeed.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Now further know, my Lords,
I am Anthynus,
The Son of that old honeſt Lord, 'gainſt whom
Your ſulphurous malice kindled the Queens anger.

sp.speaker: Elkw.
sp.l: Who'l have an head now for an half penny?

sp.speaker: Kelr.
sp.l: And for tother two Tokens mine into the Bargain.

div.stage: Enter Keeper, with Oſriick, Ethelſwick, Edith, Alfride, Edelred, Guard.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: Make way there for the Priſoner.

sp.speaker: Eauf.
sp.l: See King Oſriick.

sp.speaker: Theodw.
sp.l: I, this is our King indeed.

sp.speaker: Theodr.
sp.l: O let me waſh your feet Sir with my tears.

sp.speaker: Oſr.
sp.l: Thy treſpaſſe is thine honour my Theodrick.
And I muſt thank your care my Lords, as it deſerves,
Your over-reaching care to give my Dignity
As much as in you lay unto another.
And for your betters counterfeit in my name,
By which the Queen is mock'd into a marriage.

sp.speaker: Theodw.
sp.l: That was your policy, your wit, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Eauf.
sp.l: A ſhame on't. would I were hang'd, that I
Might hear no more on't.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Fair Sir, the Queen is pleas'd, and hopes you are
In her that's ſo much fairer in your thoughts,

sp.speaker: Anth
sp.l: My Siſter Mildred.

sp.speaker: Oſr.
sp.l: Yet, my noble Brother,
She ſtands in fortune equal with your ſelf,
In being mine.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: But not great Sir, untill
You are acquitted of my fathers murder.

sp.speaker: Oſr.
sp.l: I am clear of that, as I am not Anthynus.
Anthynus is accus'd, not Oſriick Sir,
Your father is required at your hands.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: But his accuſer reads another leſſon
Now Madam.
sp.stage: Offa brought bound in a Chair.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Whither do you hurry me!
If I muſt anſwer't give me yet ſome time,
To make proviſion of befitting Preſents,
To ſupply the hard hands of my ſtern Judges,
Into a tender feeling of my cauſe:

I know what Eacus loves, what Min •…
likes,
And what will make grave Radam •… thus run.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: He is diſtracted.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Yes, and ſpeaks hainous things
Againſt himſelf, both of my Lords murder,
And an intended rape againſt his Siſter.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Inceſtuous monſter!

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Hark, how the Divel lies;
I have no Siſter.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: How he's poſſeſs'd
Of that ſtrange error? I muſt ſatisfie you;
That was meerly feign'd by me to ſave her honour
From his outragious luſt.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: But here comes that
Clears all at once.
Welcome my honour'd Lords.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.l: A boon, a boon, my gratious Liege.

sp.speaker: Arn
sp.l: Hold your peace fool.

sp.speaker: Seg.
sp.l: My Son Anthynus living?

sp.speaker: Oſr.
sp.l: You are my Father in your Daughters-right.

sp.speaker: Seg.
sp.l: My bleſſing on my Girle.

sp.speaker: Oſr.
sp.l: But ſee Anthynus at a greater height.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: My Father.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: And my Father noble Sir.
Your pardon, and for ever welcome.

sp.speaker: Seg.
sp.l: If this were real now, and not a Dream!

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.l: Come, leave your fooling, hear a wiſe man ſpeak:
Great King according unto thy beheſt
With Knights adventurers I went in queſt,
Through the Woods and Forreſts wild
To ſcoure the Dens of Outlaws vild;
Whence theſe old men, this Knave I bring
Together with this Starveling;
Whom I preſent not dead, but quick
Unto thy grace King Oſriick.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Look this way fool,
This is King Oſriick man.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.l: Whoſe fool am I then?

sp.speaker: Oſr.
sp.l: Mine.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: And mine.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Mine.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: And mine.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.l: Whoop, hold a little, beſt let me be every bodies fool
Round about the houſe.
But amongſt you all, let me not loſe reward;
I muſt not fool for nought; the times are hard.

sp.speaker: Oſr.
sp.l: Still the fool's covetous.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: I ow thee a juſt reward, for I proclaim'd
To him that brought this man alive or dead
A thouſand crowns; but ſince 〈…〉 ſo fortunate
To bring him home alive and well recover'd
Out of ſuch danger—

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.l: I ſhall have nothing ſhall I?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: I'l double thy reward, give thee two thouſand crows.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.l: It is enough in conſcience; who bids more?
For till you are out-bidden, I'l be your fool.
But can you tell whoſe Favourite you are then?

sp.speaker: Theodr
sp.l: Where I was firſt, I'l ever wiſh to be.

sp.speaker: Oſr.
sp.l: And I'l be thine Theodrick; for thou in this
Haſt above favour ſhewn me unto bliſſe.

sp.speaker: Seg.
sp.l: I have perform'd your Majeſties command,
Though not in ſending, yet in bringing home
My baniſh'd friend, Lord Alberto, the preſerver
Of my now happy life.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: It ſhall be to his honour; welcome Alberto.

sp.speaker: Outl.
sp.l: Oh what an heavenly ſmell of meat is here!

sp.speaker: Seg.
sp.l: All the unhappineſs I now can ſee
Is but an argument of tears for thee,
In whom I'm juſtly puniſh'd.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Take him hence
From my grieved fathers ſight.

sp.speaker: Seg.
sp.l: And pray let care
Be had for his recovery; his ſenſes may
Bring a new ſoul into him, for which I pray.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: What am I freed?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Yes, yes, my Lord, all's well.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: I knew my bribes would do it.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.l: I'l off with him, for 'tis unknown to you
What good a fool may on a mad man do.

sp.speaker: Seg.
sp.l: This ſword was evidence enough againſt him;
But here's one of the Outlaws that confeſs'd it;
For whom, ſince he is penitent, I beg pardon.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: The other two his fellows are both extant:
For whom together with three theeviſh workmen
That were ſtrong inſtruments in my delivery,
Let me beg mercy.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: I have heard of them that robb'd my brothers Jewel-houſe.
'Tis a day of grace,
And we are taught by heavens abundant mercy
Shewn upon us beyond our expectation,
To imitate that goodneſſe.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: I forgive
All on my part.

sp.speaker: Oſr.
sp.l: I pardon all on mine.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: And now right royal Sir, let me entreat
For former love, to make our laſt compleat,
You will be pleas'd a month with us to ſtay
In triumphs to commemorate this day.

sp.speaker: Oſr.
sp.l: Next to my ſum of happineſſe my Bride,
I ſhould have ſought that honour, royal Siſter.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Thus through tempeſtuous ſighs and ſhowres of tears
Joy at the laſt more cheerfully appears.

div.closer: RIC. BROME. Deus dedit his quoque Finem.
